string.text: They call that thing the “pseudoflesh,” and it's not as easy to deal with as a regular flesh… Many people tell stories about it, and even though I don't really care much for legends, when I saw the creature myself, I realized that all the stories about it were true.\n \nI remember this one time, I was walking around the Garbage when I heard a cry for help. I crouched down and slowly started to make my way towards the screams, but then I noticed something was off… The speech was all slurred, and I could barely understand what was being said. So, anyway, I crawled up to an old Kamaz car and hid behind the hood. I took a peek, and you wouldn't believe what I saw and heard… That pseudoflesh was screaming like a human being. I wanted to kill it as quickly as possible, but I couldn't get my gun out in time, and it escaped.
Interesting story. And you think the mutant is wandering around here?

Yeah. I'm telling you, its lair is somewhere out there. It's been acting too calm recently. In that area, there's a small cave where, even in very hot and sunny days, it still remains moist. The pseudoflesh is most likely inside. When we get closer, you should attack from the hill on the right side while I attack from the left. When you catch sight of that awful creature, make it run towards me, and I'll finish it off. But watch your back; there might be other mutants there.
Got it. We headin' out now?
Yeah. We should go. If all the things they say about it are true… We need to get rid of this problem right now.
Lead the way.

Yeah! We did it! We finally slayed that god awful creature. That's the one; I'm sure of it. Just like when I saw it back then.\n \nWell, a deal's a deal. You've helped me, and in return, I'll help you. When I leave the Outpost, I'll take you with me. Also, here. Take this. Extra payment for a job well done.
Don't mention it. If you need anything else, you know where to find me. What are we gonna do now?

I'll keep that in mind. Well, you can go back to base. As for me, I want to study this mutant a bit. Maybe I can take something that's worth selling. When I leave the Outpost, I'll send you a message.
Hello there, merc! I take it you talked to Rasputin?
All right. See you later!
Listen, I can't seem to find it… The damn thing's probably hiding somewhere, and finding it is going to take forever.
Maybe someone killed it already?

I highly doubt that. We'd definitely know about anyone killing it. You know how much hunters like bragging about their spoils? If one of them would have hunted down the creature, then the entire Outpost would know about it.
All right. So what are we going to do now?
Okay… We need to inspect the other part of this dump. Let's head over to the spot where I first saw it. Maybe we'll find it there.
All right. Let's go, then…
You can go back to base. When I leave the Outpost, I'll message you.
Yeah. I talked to him. Listen, Rasputin said that you were able to get me out of the Outpost. Is that true?
So Rasputin said that you, along with some other stalker—Savage, I think—tried to blow up the Monolith construction site. Did you manage to pull it off?
No. I don't want to talk about it. Can we leave the Outpost already?
Well, yeah. That's why I came here. I'm going to the bar; I have some business there. And after that, I'm heading to Yantar. If you want, you can come with. I'm heading out right now; you ready?
Yeah. I'm ready. Let's go.
Sure I can do that, but not for free. Money is not what I need, though. Instead, I need your help with a mission. If you help me with that, then I'll take you with me when I leave the Outpost. Deal?
All right. What sort of help do you need?
I need your help with finding and killing a certain mutant.
Why won't you ask any of the hunters? They have more experience with that sort of thing.

Well, the thing is that I'm hunting this mutant for the scientists; they've asked me to bring them a piece of its flesh for further research. They promised to pay me a hefty sum for a job well done, but if I take the entire group, then everyone would want a piece, and there's not enough to go around for everyone. Bringing just one man with me is also out of the question, as it can lead to some unnecessary conflict, if you know what I mean. I'd rather take someone from outside our group and not tell them about this in first place. It's better that way. So are you in?
Sure. I'll help you. First, though, tell me what mutant we're hunting here.
Hey, Beast. What's up?

Not yet… and I doubt I'll ever forget about it. Either way, we made it out, and that's what's important. Now we can carry on with our lives. Perhaps I'll see my family again soon. Right now, though, I'd like some time to myself. I'll talk to you later…
All right. I hope everything turns out well for you.
Finally you're out. Man, was that Saurel guy stubborn, but I did manage to convince him to free you. How are you feeling?
Not too bad… By the way, the guard told me that Marcus didn't make it out of the anomaly. What the hell happened?

Yeah… It's true we couldn't contact you or Marcus, so Forester went back to look for the two of you, but he only found you. I hope he's all right. Being trapped alone inside the spatial anomaly must be maddening… Let's hope that Forester can reach the Red Forest so he can send Marcus the coordinates and help him escape.
Yeah. Let's hope he finds his way out. So how's everyone else? Is anyone from our group still here?
No. Everyone left with the guide yesterday. You can't blame them, though, after what they've been through. I wouldn't be surprised if they end up leaving the Zone after this.
All right… And what about you? What plans do you have for the future?
I'm not planning to go anywhere any time soon; I've decided to stay at the Outpost for a while and try to forget about that godforsaken anomaly.
And have you managed to forget about it, even slightly?
Looks like it's over… Thanks, merc. We wouldn't have pulled it off alone.

Don't thank me just yet. There's still a chance the bandits could attack again. Saurel told me you found out about this attack by listening in on the bandits' hidden radio frequency, right? Do you have a radio tuned to their frequency?
I do. We should check if anyone was able to inform the bandits about our ambush.
Yeah. We need to know what the bandits are planning.
Damn it. They're sending another squad here. What should we do, merc?
Don't panic. You two should get back to your position and prepare for our “guests.” I'm going back to my sniping position in the attic.
Yeah, yeah. I know that already. Just listen 'til the end and then decide, okay?
Go on, then.

I bet you know about the big Monolith platoon that settled down nearby, right? Those assholes have been a pain in everyone's ass for a long time; both for us and for the stalkers on the farm. Those psychos have killed five of my guys. I doubt I need to tell you how many problems they cause for us, and for you too.
And?

To make matters worse, they get backup and ammunition from somewhere, and their base is constantly growing. Soon, there won't be enough room for all of them. They'll take over the whole Outpost, and they'll kill us all off in the process. It seems the only option is to get out of here, but not too long ago, we managed to find out who's in command of the platoon. Werewolf is his name, but that's not all: we also know how to kill him without taking any casualties. And perhaps even wipe out some of his close friends while we're at it.
Interesting… And how do you plan to kill him?

We'll swat him like a fly. Two days ago, one of my fighters pulled a guy out of a Zharka. Well, he turned out be from the Monolith… and not just any regular cultist, but one of the high ranks in Werewolf's platoon. We managed to get some info out of him. It turns out that tomorrow, Werewolf is heading to a meeting with some other high ranking Monolith officer. This meeting will take place in the factory with minimal security.
And you think two important Monolith officers won't have good security with them?

I never said that. Obviously, Werewolf's guards and that other dude would be real professionals, but the thing is that this meeting is so secret that a regular Monolith fighter won't even know about it. We need all the help we can get here. To tell you the truth, I didn't want any outside help at first, but because these assholes iced five of our best guys, we have little to no chance of pulling off this operation alone now. That's why we're taking all the help we can find, and we could really use the help of a skilled fighter such as yourself. So what do you say?
I need to think about it.
No pasaran! Good to see you, Beast!
All right, Miklukha. I'll go with you.

There's no time to think. The meeting is going to take place soon, so we need to start the assault ASAP. More than that, though, we probably won't get another chance like this one seeing how the number of Monolith troops keeps increasing, and soon, they'll wipe us all out.
I knew you were a real man.\n \nAll right. If you're in, then we should get going at once and prepare for the ambush at the factory.
Lead the way.
I can't talk now, Beast. I'm too busy…
Do I know you?
Oh, yeah. Forgot to introduce myself. My name's Miklukha; commander of this Freedom squad. As for you, there's no need to introduce yourself. I've already heard all about you.
And what have you heard about me?
Nothing too good, to be honest. However, I do know for a fact that you are a professional, and I just so happen to need someone like you for a job.
What's the job?
I need someone very dangerous taken out.
Sorry, but I can't help you with that. I'm done being a hitman.
Greetings, servant of the Monolith. What brings you here?
We came here to strengthen the Monolith's might on this earth.
We did not expect any reinforcements today… Where do you come from, and why are there only two of you?

Um… I was sent here by my priest, along with five others. We came here through Limansk. Our path was full of tests and challenges that the Monolith prepared for us. However, not everyone withstood the Monolith's test, and only two of us survived. We were supposed to arrive here a few days later, but the Monolith showed us a faster way.
Praise the Monolith for guiding you here. If you did not die on the way here, the Monolith has chosen you. You are needed here.
I'll be on my way.

Thank the Monolith, infidel, for he is the one who spared your life… If it was up to me, I would have killed you on the spot. But the Monolith forbids me to do so because he chose you for his trial. We are holding your friend hostage, in case you want to save him.
You have Savage? What sick game are you playing?

Silence, infidel! I am the only one who is allowed to speak here. Our prophet took your friend away to the north. I've marked the exact location on your PDA. If you want to save him, I suggest you go there.
I don't need your suggestions on what to do.
All right. We're here. I'm going to stay on the farm for a while. If you need my services, I'll be here in the neighboring house. Good luck, merc.
You too.
Hey, merc. You need to get somewhere?
Can you get me to the metallurgical factory?
Not yet.
Sure I can. And since you're on an assignment for Saurel, I won't charge you anything this trip. So, are you ready to move out?
Yeah. Let's go.

Hey, there, merc. You the one who whacked these bandits? I was nearby and heard some gunshots, so I decided to check what's up. I thought the bandits were attacking stalkers again, so I wanted to lend a hand. But I see you managed all by yourself. What about you? You looking for something, or are you just passing through?
Well, we're here. I'll stay here and wait for you. When you decide to get back to the northern farm, come see me again. Just keep in mind that I won't wait here *too* long.
All right, then. I don't think I'll be long.
So, merc, are you ready to get back to the northern farm?
Yeah. We need to tell Saurel that someone killed Lefty.
Yeah. It's a bit of a shituation, if you ask me… Lefty was a good dude, even though he did kill his friend.
I doubt Lefty's the one behind Lame's murder. Lefty also got killed. The real killer's probably trying to tie up any loose ends.
If you say so. It's none of my business anyway. We heading back to the farm?
Yeah. Let's go.
I was sent here by Saurel; that's all you need to know.
Hey, merc. You need to get somewhere?
I need to get to the metal factory again. Will you get me there?
Of course. Tit for tat. Ready to go?
Yeah. Let's move.
Ready to go back to the farm?
Yeah. Let's move.
I need to get to the anomalous grove. Can you get me there?

I'd be happy to get you there, but the problem is that the place is always filled with either boars or bandits. I'd much rather just get you to the farm that's nearby. It's a lot safer. From there, you can continue on your own, or I can get you to the nearby metal factory, if you'd like. So what do you say?
A Freedomer by the name of Miklukha told me to come by; he gave me his coordinates. His location is far off, and I need someone to show me a safe path. Can you do that?

So you're that mercenary who got out of the spatial anomaly with some other stalkers? In that case, I won't ask any questions. Just one thing, though: are you heading to the northern farm, by any chance?
I need to get to the old school. Can you lead me there?
All right. Let's go to that farm.
Tell you what: lead me to the metal factory, and from there, I'll go on my own.
I changed my mind.
Miklukha? Yeah, I know the guy. He organized a small base with his buds in the old school. We can head out right now if you like. So, are you ready?
Yeah. Let's go.
Sorry, merc. I can't get you to the old school, seeing how Freedom's abandoned it. I heard that bandits took over that place.
Fine. Then forget about it.
Yeah. I'm going there; I need to talk to Saurel.
Will you get me to the Panskiy farm?
Yeah. No problem. Are you ready?
Yeah. Let's go.
Sure. No problem. Ready to move out now?
Yeah. Let's go.
Wanna go together? I know all the safe routes around these parts. Plus, it'll be less boring that way…
Are you a guide? Can you get me out of the Outpost?

Nah. I'm just a guy who knows the ins and outs of this place, but as for getting out of here, that's a whole nother story. The area around the Outpost is filled with dangerous anomalies, and only a professional can get you out of here safely. We have a guide who hangs out in the farm, but I don't know if he's there right now. Uh, anyway, I got a little carried away. We heading out to the northern farm?
Yeah. Let's go.
Hey, Beast. What's up?
Saurel told me that Lefty's dead. That true?
Afraid so. Rasputin, can you help me with something? You know pretty much every stalker in the base, right?
May he rest in peace… As for the stalkers here, yeah. I know all of them. I'm the barman, after all. Why?
Can you tell me who this knife belongs to?
That's Chemist's knife. He was looking for it all over the place. He was really nervous he couldn't find it; kept yelling and cursing while messing up the place.
Where is he now?
Well, he was looking for his knife everywhere. Then he said he remembered where he left it and that he was going there to retrieve it. Give him his knife when you get the chance.
Hey, merc.
All right. I'll be on my way.
Hey, merc. You wanna buy something or what?
You here on business, Beast?
So it turned out that Chemist killed Lefty? Damn. He had us all fooled… At least that asshole's dead.
I made him pay for what he did. Listen, I still have his knife… Maybe you wanna buy it?
I made him pay for what he did.
Hmm… It's a good knife, so I'll give you three thousand rubles for it. Deal?
I'm no mercenary anymore. What do you need?
Deal. Here you go.
Nah. I'll keep it for myself.
All right. Here's your cash. So are you here on business or what?
Man, why you gotta be like that? Fine. I'll buy it for forty-five hundred rubles. That's the most I'm willing to pay for it.
Fine. Here you go.
Money's not the problem here. It's just that this knife might come in handy.
Great! Here's your cash. By the way, are you here on business, or did you just come here to sell the knife?
Fine. You don't want to sell it, that's your choice. I was wondering… Are you here on business, or did you just come here for a drink? If it's the former, I have some jobs I need taking care of.
Man, thanks for getting rid of that scumbag. I was wondering… Are you here on business, or did you just come here for a drink? If it's the former, I have some jobs I need taken care of.
Yeah. Saurel told me that you might have some jobs for me, and seeing that the guide won't be here for a while, I might as well earn some extra cash.
Sure thing, buddy… There's no such thing as a former mercenary. By the way, everyone here calls me Rasputin. And you're Beast, right?

Yeah. I have a job for you; nothing too hard. So one of my regulars spotted a rare artifact inside the anomalous grove near the metal factory. The artifact in question is a Kolobok, and I want it. The guy who told me about it couldn't get a hold of it. He told me that the artifact is located on the tallest tree there, and when he tried to get it, he fell off the tree and almost broke his neck. Anyway, can you do this for me? All you have to do get the artifact and come back here.
Are you sure it's still there?

I doubt anyone managed to get their hands on it. It's not like we have any rock climbers here. I'll even part with a Veles detector so you can find what I need more easily. And if you find any other artifacts, they're yours. Or you can sell them to me. So are you in?
All right. I'll get you that artifact.
Great! Here's the detector and coordinates to that place, in case you forget where it is.
Got it. I'll be on my way.
Did you get that artifact yet?
Yeah. I have the artifact. Wasn't easy to get a hold of. What's more is that after I got it, I was ambushed by bandits.
No kidding? And what did you do?
I am…
It doesn't matter. What matters is that I got the artifact, safe and sound.
Nothing. I just ran off with the artifact. They couldn't catch up to me.
Not yet.
You did the right thing. They got what they deserved. The bandits have really gotten out of control, and this isn't the first time they go robbing someone here.\n \nAll right. Give me that artifact.
Here you go.
Man, these bandits have gotten out of control; not the first time they pull this shit. I need to tell Saurel about this. Give me the artifact.
Here you go.

And here's your reward, just like I promised. If you find any more artifacts, bring them here. I'll buy them off you for a higher price than anyone else around here; you can trust me on that. By the way, Saurel said he wanted to see you.
Here's your reward. Pleasure doing business with you, merc.
All right. I'll go see what he wants.

Listen, Beast: I know that Saurel told you to deal with Lefty, but I doubt he's the one behind Lame's murder. They were good friends, and they could kill for one another. They always went on raids together; practically best friends. I've never seen a friendship as tight as theirs.
Welcome to my bar, Beast. Are you here on business, or do you want a drink?
I had the artifact, but it was stolen by bandits.
What?! And you just let them take it? I know you quit being a mercenary, but this is too much. How could you just let them take the artifact? I never thought you'd do something like this.
I don't care what you think. I'm not going to risk my life for your artifact.
Whatever. No point in arguing over it now. I should have asked someone else to this job anyway. Ugh… By the way, Saurel told me he wants to see you.
Okay. I'll go talk to him. Later.

Greetings, Beast! Listen: a mutant hunter came to the Outpost not too long ago. He said he needs a good marksman for a job, so I instantly thought of you. He leads the group of hunters that hangs out near the wagon, and he goes by “Hunter.” Have you heard about him before?
No. Haven't heard of him. That's one ridiculous name, by the way: Hunter the hunter. Do you know anything about him?
So what? They were both drunk off their asses. Besides, I've seen similar things happen before.

Oh, yeah. I have plenty of stories about Hunter. I've known him for a long time. As a matter of fact, everyone knows and respects him… and some even fear him. He's a good friend and partner, and a good fighter. He's been everywhere in the Zone; came here in 2006. He himself said that the Zone is the best place for him. He adapted to this place quickly because he was a hunter before coming to the Zone.\n \nAfter he entered the Zone, he started selling mutant parts to people who needed them in the outside world. For a while, he also worked as a guide for tourists who wanted to see the Zone and hunt small mutants for fun. There's rich people who would pay for something like that. One guy, an American, came here to make a documentary film about the Zone… He died. That was the first and last tourist lead by Hunter. Since then, he stopped working as a guide for tourists. It's also where Hunter got his nickname. The American kept calling him “Hunter.”
What does he need done?
I didn't ask him that. Why don't you go talk to him and see what he wants?
All right. I'll go talk to him.
Welcome to my bar, Beast. Are you here on business, or just to have a drink?

I think you'll make the right choice… By the way, if you want to make some extra cash, bring me some mutant parts, and I'll pay for them. It's one of the easiest ways to make money here at the Outpost, if you know how to field dress a mutant.
I'll keep that in mind.

Even if he was drunk, Lefty's not the kind of guy who would kill his best friend. Beast, I'm only asking to let Lefty explain himself before you do anything to him. Maybe he can convince you otherwise.
All right. We'll see how things pan out.
Well, he couldn't have gotten very far. Besides that, he's still here at the Outpost, although I don't know his exact whereabouts.
All right. I'll try to find him.
What's up, merc?
So, Beast, have you dealt with our problem?
Haven't discovered the real killer yet, so no.
What's that supposed to mean?

Lefty didn't kill Lame. I talked to him, and I could tell he wasn't lying. He told me about how he and Lame got a hold of some good loot and that they were drinking to celebrate. When they were drinking, they told a few other guys about their discovery; hence, Lefty's not the only one with a reason to kill Lame. Also, when Lefty disappeared after arguing with Lame, he was captured by bandits, so that means he couldn't have made it back to base. It's very unlikely that Lefty is behind Lame's death.
All right. Tell you what: bring Lefty here, and we'll question everyone who drank with him that night. I won't tolerate rats and murderers around here.
Listen up, merc. I've heard about your line of “work,” and if you try anything funny, I will deal with you accordingly. Are we clear on that?
All right. I'll go get Lefty.
Beast, where's Lefty? Did you bring him to our base?
Lefty's dead. The killer is “cleaning up” after himself.
That bastard… We need to find whoever's behind this as soon as possible.

Let's not rush this. It's not like we can revive the dead, and if we make a move too early, more innocent people might get hurt. But don't worry. I'll find out who did this, and I'll deal with them. All right?
Fair enough. As long as you get it done.
By the way, did you find out who drank with the victims?
Yeah. There were two other men: Burnt and Chemist.
I'll find out soon enough.
Don't worry. After I went through in the space anomaly, I've decided to move on from my past. I'm tired of it.
Beast, go find Lefty. We'll talk later.
So, Beast, any luck finding the murderer?
Not yet.
So, Beast, any luck finding the murderer?
Yeah: it was Chemist. He wanted the loot to himself, so he snuffed out both of them.

What? Are you sure? I never thought Chemist would do something like this… He was one of my best and most trusted men, and what a piece of shit he turned out to be… May both Lame and Lefty rest in peace. They were good stalkers too.
What's done is done. What's important is that we've avenged Lame's death.
I see. And how are you feeling?

What is this world coming to?… I still can't believe Chemist did this. He was the last I'd suspect; I even considered putting Burnt in the cage, but after questioning him, I was convinced he wasn't guilty.\n \nHere. Take this. It's your reward for helping us out. You helped us get rid of a huge menace, and that's worth a lot.
Thanks, and goodbye. This is probably the last time we'll ever see each other.
Hey. Wait up. Where are you going?
I'm leaving the Outpost. I don't like it here.
So nobody told you?
About what?

There's no way out of the Outpost right now; every way out is blocked off. One path has been taken over by Monolith, who are constantly patrolling it. The second path is covered by anomalies, and only an experienced guide can lead you through it safely… and our guide is gone right now. He's out escorting a group of stalkers through the Red Forest, and you're going to have to wait until he comes back.
Goddamn it… All right, then. Guess I'll have to be your guest for a while. Do you have any more jobs for me?
Not right now, but if you need work, go talk to Rasputin. He always has something that needs doing.
Understood. See you!
Tanned and rested. Your jail cells are like a holiday resort…
What's up, Beast?
It's a good thing you came by, Beast. A few problems have popped up, and I need you to help me out with them.
What's up?

We managed to find a hidden radio frequency used by the bandits, so we tuned our radios to it. One day, when we were listening in, we overheard the bandits planning an attack on our base at night. They're planning on freeing the captive bandits here, and we need to halt their advance. Will you give us a hand?
Sure. I'll help. What's the plan?

The plan is this: we seize control of the farm near the anomalous grove, and when the bandits get close, three of us will take them at the front, one man will take up a sniper position, and the rest will open fire at them from the abandoned buildings nearby. The bandits have no idea about our counterattack, so that should give us a great advantage.
I'll take the sniper position. I've done sniping contracts plenty of times.
All right. I'll make sure to supply you with all the necessary gear. Anyway, I suggest you get ready; our ambush is taking place tonight.

Sorry about locking you up, but we had to take measures. Savage vouched for you and told me about how you helped everyone in the space anomaly, so I decided to set you free. And even though things are fine and dandy around here, we could use the help of someone like you, and seeing as my men saved you from a group of bandits, you do owe them.
All right, Saurel. I'll go get ready.
Right, right. Go get ready.
What's up, Beast?
Any news, Beast? Did you manage to fight off the bandits?
Both of your men are alive. We managed to repel the bandits as well as their backup party.
We repelled the bandits along with their backup party. However, not all of us got out alive: Tailor died.
Great news, Beast! I didn't want to interfere with the eavesdropping, so I didn't contact you through the radio. What's this “backup party” you mentioned?

After we disposed of the first group, we overheard additional bandits on the radio. They were sending a scout party to see what's going on. They probably got spooked when the first team didn't answer.
All right. What's the job?
Oh. I see… Anyway, I doubt those scumbags will ever show their faces around here again. Thanks for helping us fight them off, Beast. Here's your reward… And by the way, keep the sniper rifle.
Thank you. See you later.

May he rest in peace. He was a good stalker. He would always put his neck on the line to save his fellow stalkers. We should give him a proper burial… You said something about a second group of bandits?
Hey. What's up, Beast?

We had an incident the day before you came here. Long story short, we have a killer on the loose; one of our stalkers got his throat slit. He and his friend were squabbling about something and got into a fight, and after a while, one of them, Lame, was found dead, while his friend Lefty disappeared somewhere. Your job is to find Lefty and make him pay for his actions.
Where should I look for him?
Can you answer a few questions?
Ask away.
Tell me about yourself.
Tell me about the Zone.
Ask away, and I'll tell you what I know.
Ever since my first day here, I've been wondering: is the Zone really expanding, or is it just hearsay?

What do you think? Of course it's true. Way back when, the Zone was a lot smaller than it is now. When the Zone emerged, its borders stretched out north of Rostok. I don't know the exact boundaries, but what we do know is that the Zone's first border was somewhere around the military warehouses.
How fast is it expanding? Right now, there are plenty of anomalies here. Were they fewer here before?

Believe what you want, but a year ago, this place was completely devoid of anomalies. Five years ago, this place wasn't even considered part of the Zone, and back then, the army had an outpost in the northern part of the Garbage. But after the Zone started to expand, the military was forced to relocate. I have no idea how it's expanding so rapidly, and that's something for the eggheads at Yantar to deal with. Not me.\n \nThe Zone expands in bursts; usually after an emission. Back then, emissions were a lot more scarce. They would take place about once a month, and they were a lot more powerful than they are right now. The Zone would expand with every blowout; however, with time, the blowouts have started to diminish in power, though they occur a lot more frequently these days. We now have a blowout every few days, but it wasn't always like that.
What's gonna happen to the Zone's barrier? From what I understand, it's not the first border set up by the government.

Well, you got that right. The barrier in the Cordon is the third border they've set up until now. They started building it when the Zone began to expand for the first time. Back then, a lot of people died near the perimeter; some died from the blowout, but most of them died from mutant attacks. Nobody ever saw anything like it before. The number of mutants coming from the center was enormous; there were thousands of them. In turn, the government sent everything they had at them. They turned this place into a war zone. Tanks, helicopters, artillery, and everything in between was stationed here to fight off the insane waves of mutants. At one point, they considered carpet bombing the whole area, but luckily for us, the mutants stopped flooding the Zone at that point. After the incident, the surrounding world started taking the Zone a lot more seriously. Instead of restoring the old perimeter, they put a few pillboxes around the Garbage, and they didn't stop there. In case a threat were to break through the Garbage, they would have a backup solution. The military outpost in the Cordon used to be that backup solution.

Why does the Cordon outpost look so weird? What I mean is, why does it look like a military warehouse more than anything? Same thing with the wall they built around the Zone. Why does it go over the perimeter?

That's because that place was never supposed to be a military outpost but rather a warehouse where all sorts of military technology would be stored and repaired. It was also used to repair and refuel vehicles that would carry cargo in and out of the CNPP. And after the mutant breakout that I mentioned earlier, the military took over that warehouse and made it their base. As for the wall, they only started building it after the blowout struck. Because the engineers worked in a hurry, they made some kind of calculation error. As a result, the wall was actually built south of the outpost. Eventually, they tried to rebuild it so that the wall would at least cover some of the outside buildings, and the result is what you see today.
Where are the gates, though? When I looked, there was no gate. Just an open entrance.

They're not there anymore. They got rid of them. A few months ago, a big flock of mutants smashed through those gates. The strange thing was that there were no blowouts that day. Out of nowhere, a flock of boars and flesh appeared and started breaking through the barrier, slaughtering a few soldiers in the process. Then, when the military called in a chopper, something completely bizarre happened: the mutants instantly ran away as if they knew something was coming. Instead of repairing the gates, they decided to just get rid of them, seeing as they were going to build a second barrier anyway. Did you see it, by the way? It looks amazing; a fine piece of work indeed. Everything there is as it should be: flamethrowers, mortars, fortified trenches, and pillboxes; it's all there. Hell, the minefield alone is a work of art. Not a single rodent gets past it. They must've spent billions, considering all the gear that's located there. Seems like NATO takes its defense budget seriously.
Thanks for the info.

Thanks for the info.
What exactly do you want to know?
Know anything interesting?
Did you hear about the American spies?
Nope. What about them?

Well, a year ago, Rasputin got a job to escort three foreigners through the Zone. He was promised very good pay, so he agreed. However, he's a smart guy, so he checked out what they had in store for him. He found out through his sources that those foreigners were no regular tourists but rather CIA agents. Rasputin didn't want to lose the cash he was promised, but at the same time, he didn't want to screw over the stalker that would take the job.
So what did he do?

He told me about his situation, and after a while, we both came up with a solution. We picked someone who could really handle himself: Elijah Muromskiy. That guy was tough as nails: two meters tall, huge shoulders, and strong as hell. One time, he broke a boar's neck with his bare hands just for the hell of it. If anything ever went down, he could handle it.
So what happened then?

Elijah arrived on time and met the tourists, after which he led them to the designated areas. The tourists wanted to inspect the mutants from afar and take a few pictures, and maybe even hunt a few of them. But Elijah could barely speak any English, and he couldn't understand what his clients wanted from him. They only thing Elijah understood was that our guests wanted to hunt down some mutants, and so that's what he did for the entire trip.
I think I know where this is going…

Nah, you don't. Shut up and listen: for three days, Elijah escorted our American clients. He went everywhere with these guys and showed them everything. In the Agroprom underground, they were attacked by a bloodsucker that almost killed one of the tourists. In Yantar, Elijah “accidentally” forgot to mention that there were zombies there, so when one of the corpses stood up, one guy almost had a heart attack. When they were traveling between one location and another, he would “accidentally” run into flocks of boars and other small time mutants. On the third day, Elijah suggested they sleep in the construction site in the Dark Valley. He, of course, “forgot” to bring up the presence of burers there. I don't even know who was more scared: the burers at the sight of Elijah or the Americans who were terrified by the burers. When Elijah told us about this, we all burst out laughing.\n \nThat's not all, though. The next morning, the tourists wanted to go home, so they went to Sidorovich so that he could smuggle them back across the border. However, the same day the tourists planned to leave, a group of three guys came to the Zone. They were escorted through the border by the military. It turned out that this was a CIA group sent into the Zone for some kind special preparation program. Sidorovich was dumbfounded: why send one CIA group and then another one right after? He asked the tourists why the CIA did this, to which they replyed—in broken Russian—that they weren't CIA and had nothing to do with them.
So the whole time, Elijah was just scaring a few American tourists… Ha ha ha! Damn. That's too damn funny.
Yeah. He almost gave them a heart attack. By the way, Elijah also escorted the real spies, in the same route. The burers were happy about it, though! Ha!
Thanks. I needed a good laugh.
Thanks for the info.

Where are you from?
I was born in Okha, which is in Sakhalin. You know where that is, right?
Sakhalin? Of course I know where it is. It's an island in the far east of Russia, close to Japan. You sure traveled a long way to get here. What did you do there?

Well, it was a town full of workers. The town's main export was gas and oil and even wood. I could always find work in those area. But ever since my childhood, I had a need for adventure. I just couldn't imagine myself being stuck in one place for the rest of my life. At the time, I traveled through every forest in the region. When I turned eighteen, I joined the military. For me, it was the only way to get off that island and see the world.
Thanks for the info.
How did you end up in the Zone?

That's a tough one…
 
I don't know whether it was a chain of coincidences or if the Zone itself chose me, but here I am. Back in the army, I did well at everything. I've loved sports since I was a little kid, so even two years in the Spetsnaz wasn't too bad for me. Though, the war in Afghanistan was coming to an end; I was barely sent to any war zones, and I didn't see a lot of fighting, which was lucky for me. When the war finally ended, I was sent to military school, where I got a military career.
 
While I was in school, I met a woman who I eventually married. I didn't have any kids, though, but that turned out for the best. After I finished school, I would travel from garrison to garrison, so I didn't have time to raise any children. And then I was sent to Chechnya. That's where I lost my Marina… I was a complete dimwit for bringing her with me there in spite of warnings from my officers about attacks by Dadaev forces. And I… I'm such an idiot: I couldn't save her.
Didn't mean to remind you… Sorry. I didn't know.

Forget about it. It's my cross to bear, and I'll have to live with it for the rest of my life. Maybe that's why the Zone led me here. What do you think? I've been through a lot after the First Chechen War; so much that I can't even tell you about it right now. Nevertheless, I remember the day the Zone emerged like it was yesterday. You just can't ever forget such chaos.
 
In the first few hours, nobody could even understand what was going on. People weren't sure whether the reactor exploded, a meteorite fell, or if it was the beginning of a nuclear war. Moscow was just as riled up as Kiev was. That was around the time we were sent to the Zone. I'll never forget that day. I almost lost my entire team because of those bureaucratic rats. To them, it was no big deal—throwing soldiers' lives away—considering they just had to know what those anomalies were capable of… The bastards. I still don't know how Dima, Sergey, and I made it out alive. The Zone must have guided us.
 
Anyway, when we made it back to the HQ, I was ready to shoot the general who ordered the operation. And I almost did it; I had the gun pointed between his eyes. But I was captured. After that, I was thrown in jail. If it wasn't for my friends who helped me escape, I'd probably be stuck somewhere in Russia right now, behind bars. After I escaped the military camp, I had two choices: either live in the Zone or spend the rest of my life hiding in the outside world. I choose the former. I'd rather live freely in the Zone than rot in some shitty prison.
That's one hell of a story. Do you ever miss your hometown?

You know, at first, I didn't miss it at all; I was too busy trying to stay alive. Back then, the Zone was a lot more dangerous than it is now, and it was almost completely devoid of people to boot. Even though I'm an experienced soldier who's seen all the horrors of war, none of those horrors could compare to what I've seen in the Zone. When your friend gets caught in an anomaly, flies up into the air, and gets torn to shreds, there's nothing you can feel but pure fear. Nevertheless, you can't lose your skill and experience, and so I managed to survive somehow. After some time, when I gained some experience and got a bit more comfortable here, that's when I started to feel a longing for home. Nowadays, I really want to go home and see my parents one last time; I don't even know if they're alive or not. I'd even go back to prison if it means seeing my hometown again.
Thanks for the info.
